name: Disk latency is high for host {{host.name}} on device {{device.name}}
message:
## 🚨 What’s happening

High disk I/O wait time detected on host {{host.name}}.

This means one or more devices on the host are taking a long time to complete disk operations — averaging over 500ms in the last 5 minutes. High I/O wait time typically occurs when the system is frequently waiting for disk reads or writes to finish, often due to storage contention or inefficient disk usage by running processes.

---

## 📈 Impact

If I/O wait remains high, it can lead to:

- Slower application and system performance, especially for disk-intensive services
- Delayed job processing or database queries
- Risk of timeouts or service degradation due to blocked I/O operations

Sustained disk latency can have cascading effects on dependent services and degrade user experience.

---

## 🛠 How to fix (Runbook)

### 🔍 Initial troubleshooting

1. Identify the affected host and device from the alert.
2. Open [**Infrastructure > Host Details**](/infrastructure) for {{host.name}}.
3. In the **Metrics tab**, examine:
   - `system.io.await` by device
   - `system.disk.read_time`, `system.disk.write_time`, `system.disk.in_use`
4. Use [**Live Processes**](/process) to find I/O-heavy processes.
5. SSH into the host and run:
   ```bash
   iostat -xd 1 3
   
### Cause and Resolution

Cause | Resolution
------|------
Disk-heavy processes | Restart or optimize services with high I/O usage
------|------
Backup jobs, ETLs, logging | Schedule or throttle non-critical workloads
------|------
Underlying disk performance | Check for slow or saturated disks, especially on network-attached volumes (e.g., EBS, NFS)
------|------
Scale-out option | Move I/O-intensive tasks to separate or faster storage tiers
